abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The present study investigated two single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs)—rs479200 and rs516651 in the host <jats:italic>EGLN1</jats:italic>/<jats:italic>PHD2</jats:italic> gene for their association with COVID-19 severity. A retrospective cohort of 158 COVID-19 patients from the Indian population (March 2020 to June 2021) was enrolled. Notably, the frequency of C allele (0.664) was twofold higher than T allele (0.336) in severe COVID-19 patients. Here, we report a novel finding that the C allele of rs479200 in the <jats:italic>EGLN1</jats:italic> gene imparts a high risk of severe COVID-19 (odds ratio—6.214 (1.84–20.99) <jats:italic>p</jats:italic> = 0.003; 9.421 (2.019–43.957) <jats:italic>p</jats:italic> = 0.004), in additive inheritance model (adjusted and unadjusted, respectively).</jats:p>

group.label: Ethics approval and consent to participate
group.name: EthicsHeading

assertion.name: Ethics
assertion.value: The study was approved by the Institutional Ethics Committees (IECs), AIIMS, Raipur [1379/IEC-AIIMSRPR/2020] & ICMR-NIMR, Delhi [PHB/NIMR/EC/2020/145]. All the participants consented to sample collection and the subjects were included in the study with approval from the IECs of the respective institutes.

assertion.name: Ethics
assertion.value: The authors declare no conflicts of interest.
